description: From Middle English den, from Old English denn (“den, lair (of a beast), cave; a swine-pasture, a woodland pasture for swine”), from Proto-West Germanic *dani (“threshing-floor, barn-floor”). Cognate with Scots den (“den, lair”), Middle Dutch denne (“burrow, den, cave, attic”), Dutch den (“ship's deck, threshing-floor, mountain floor”), Middle Low German denne, danne (“threshing-floor, small dale”), German Tenne (“threshing-floor, barn for threshing”).

entries.meaning: A small cavern or hollow place in the side of a hill, or among rocks; especially, a cave used by a wild animal for shelter or concealment.
examples: Daniel was put into the lions’ den.
Synonyms: lair; Wiktionary appendix of animal terms, including their homes

entries.meaning: A squalid or wretched place; a haunt.
examples: an opium den; a gambling den

entries.meaning: A comfortable room not used for formal entertaining.
Synonym of fort (“structure improvised from furniture, etc. for playing games.”)
examples: Our little girls love using bedsheets and other stuff around the house to make dens in the living room and pretending they're on adventures.

entries.meaning: (UK, Scotland, obsolete) A narrow glen; a ravine; a dell.
A group of Cub Scouts of the same age who work on projects together.

verbs.description: den (third-person singular simple present dens, present participle denning, simple past and past participle denned)

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To ensconce or hide oneself in (or as in) a den.

description: From Old French denier, from Latin denarius.

entries.meaning: Abbreviation of denier (a unit of weight)
(Northumbria, chiefly in place names) Alternative form of dene.
Pronunciation spelling of then, representing AAVE, Bermuda English.
